metadata.titleEn: Data set of ecological adjustment value of Arctic permafrost change on ecology system from 1982 to 2015
metadata.description: The data set of ecological adjustment value of Arctic permafrost change from 1982 to 2015, with the time resolution of 1982, 2015 and the change rate of two phases, covers the entire Arctic tundra area, with the spatial resolution of 8km. Based on multi-source remote sensing, simulation, statistics and measured data, and combined with GIS and ecological methods, it quantifies the adjustment service value of Arctic permafrost to the ecosystem, The unit price refers to the correlation (0.35) between the active layer thickness and NDVI changes after excluding precipitation and snow water equivalent, and the grassland ecosystem service value (the unit price of tundra ecosystem service is based on 1/3 of the grassland ecosystem service value).
metadata.instructions:
File name: The Arctic permafrost change ecological adjustment value data set is stored in text format. The file name is "yyyydd.txt", where yyyy represents the year and ddd represents Julian date.
Data reading method: All ASCII code files in the data set can be directly opened with a text program (such as Notepad). Except for the header file, the main content is a numerical representation of the ecological adjustment value of Arctic permafrost changes. If it is necessary to display it with a diagram, it can be opened with Arcgis. During the reading process, a file in grid format will be generated, and the displayed grid file is the graphical representation of the ASCII code file.

background: Permafrost is a subsurface phenomenon that underlies a significant part of the land and sea in the Northern Hemisphere. Permafrost stores large amounts of organic carbon, affects the stability of bedrock and unconsolidated sediments, and impacts the costs and methods used for infrastructure development. Despite its global significance, there is still no method to reliably detect the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions and at a global scale. The first comprehensive Northern Hemisphere permafrost extent map was compiled by Brown et al. (1997), based on national and regional maps and expert knowledge from different time periods and sources. High-resolution maps (up to 1km2) have been successfully produced using the TTOP (temperature at the top of permafrost) model for individual regions and countries. The TTOP approach uses only a small number of input parameters and has been successfully employed at regional and continental scales for Canada, Scandinavia, and China.
research objective: In this study, we extend and improve the remote sensing approach of Westermann et al. (2015a) and apply a TTOP–based scheme to the entire Northern Hemisphere. We compile the first permafrost temperature and zonation map at the circum-Arctic scale with a resolution of 1km2 that includes a statistical representation of subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures based on snow and landcover heterogeneity.
challenges: Despite its global significance, there is still no method to reliably detect the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions and at a global scale. Extrapolating these observations to larger regions is hampered by the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of sites that results in extensive unsampled areas.
methods: For calculation of mean annual ground temperature (MAGT), we use the CryoGrid 1 model, based on the TTOP equilibrium approach. We compile spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products. We employ the MODIS MOD11A1 and MYD11A1 level 3 product in processing version 6, which contains up to two daytime and two night-time measurements per day. Downscaling of the ERA-interim reanalysis data to the 1km2 resolution of individual MODIS pixels is accomplished by computing atmospheric lapse rates and the elevation difference between the ERA orography field and the elevation of a 1km2 pixel. We compare our ensemble MAGT mean to in-situ point measurements in 359 boreholes in the GTN-P and 392 boreholes in the TSP project network. The model calculates mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost based on mean annual air temperature (MAAT) and uses semi-empirical adjustment factors for the effects of snow cover and the thermal offset.
dataset: We compile spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products. The Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometers (MODIS) on board the Terra and Aqua satellites have provided LST measurements at a spatial resolution of 1km2 since 2000 and 2002, respectively. The study period, therefore, starts in 2000 and extends to the end of 2016. Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages.
findings: The accuracy of the modelled mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost is ±2°C when compared to permafrost borehole data. The modelled permafrost area (MAGT<0°C) covers 13.9×106 km2 (ca. 15% of the exposed land area), which is within the range or slightly below the average of previous estimates. The sum of all pixels having isolated patches, sporadic, discontinuous or continuous permafrost (permafrost probability>0) is around 21×106 km2 (22% of exposed land area), which is approximately 2×106 km2 less than estimated previously.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) in permafrost regions?
Example.Answer: The CryoGrid 1 model, based on the TTOP equilibrium approach, is used for calculating mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost. This method utilizes spatially distributed datasets of thawing degree days (TDD) and freezing degree days (FDD) derived from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when detecting permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions?
Example.Answer: A challenge in detecting permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions is the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of observation sites, which leads to extensive unsampled areas, making it difficult to extrapolate observations to larger regions.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how cloud cover affects the data collected for permafrost studies using satellite remote sensing?
Example.Answer: Extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages, which affects the accuracy of datasets compiled for studying permafrost.

Feature Specification.Question: What properties are essential for datasets used to model permafrost temperature and zonation at a circum-Arctic scale?
Feature Specification.Answer: spatially distributed data of thawing degree days (TDD), freezing degree days (FDD), remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products, snow and landcover heterogeneity, statistical representation of subpixel variability, resolution around 1km2

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of the data collection method that utilizes the TTOP-based scheme for detecting permafrost extent and temperature?
Feature Specification.Answer: mean annual ground temperature (MAGT), CryoGrid 1 model, TTOP equilibrium approach, mean annual air temperature (MAAT), semi-empirical adjustment factors for snow cover and thermal offset effects, downscaling ERA-interim reanalysis data, 1km2 resolution of MODIS pixels

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges influence the reliability of permafrost detection methods at medium to high spatial resolutions?
Feature Specification.Answer: considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime, uneven distribution of observation sites, data gaps in MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover, systematic cold bias in seasonal averages

Definition.Question: What does 'TTOP-based scheme' refer to in the context of permafrost mapping?
Definition.Answer: A 'TTOP-based scheme' refers to a method used for permafrost mapping that involves the TTOP (temperature at the top of permafrost) model. This approach uses a limited set of input parameters to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost. It has been applied at regional and continental scales and is extended for use at the circum-Arctic scale to compile permafrost temperature and zonation maps with high spatial resolution.

Definition.Question: What are 'subpixel variability' and its relevance in permafrost temperature mapping?
Definition.Answer: 'Subpixel variability' in the context of permafrost temperature mapping refers to the statistical representation of variations in permafrost temperatures within a single pixel of a map, based on factors such as snow and land cover heterogeneity. This concept is relevant as it helps in capturing the spatial variability in the thermal regime of permafrost, which is crucial for accurate mapping at high resolutions.

Definition.Question: What does 'spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD' mean in remote sensing of permafrost?
Definition.Answer: 'Spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD' refer to datasets that provide information on thawing degree days (TDD) and freezing degree days (FDD) across different geographical locations. These datasets are derived from remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) products, such as those obtained from the MODIS satellites, and are used to model mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) to assess permafrost conditions.

Interpretation.Question: How can remote sensing techniques be effectively utilized to improve the reliability of detecting permafrost occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions globally?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing techniques, such as the use of MODIS LST products, are employed to compile spatially distributed datasets of TDD and FDD. These datasets are used in conjunction with models like CryoGrid 1, which utilizes the TTOP equilibrium approach to calculate mean annual ground temperatures. This approach allows for the extension and improvement of remote sensing applications to map permafrost temperature and zonation at a circum-Arctic scale with a resolution of 1km2.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges faced in extrapolating data on permafrost to larger regions, and how can these be addressed through data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: One of the key challenges is the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of measurement sites, leading to extensive unsampled areas. Addressing these challenges involves using a combination of remote sensing data, such as MODIS LST, and models like CryoGrid 1 to estimate permafrost temperatures, while also considering snow cover and landcover heterogeneity to improve statistical representation of subpixel variability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenge in reliably detecting the occurrence and extent of permafrost at medium to high spatial resolutions on a global scale?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge is caused by the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of sites, which results in extensive unsampled areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do extended data gaps in MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover result in biases in seasonal averages when modeling permafrost extent?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Extended data gaps lead to a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages because of the inability to consistently capture land surface temperatures, which are crucial for calculating mean annual ground temperatures.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the spatial variability of ground thermal regimes affect the outcomes of permafrost temperature and zonation mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The considerable spatial variability of ground thermal regimes can result in extensive unsampled areas, which hampers the extrapolation of observations to larger regions. This variability can lead to inaccuracies in temperature and zonation mapping, making it difficult to achieve consistent results at medium to high spatial resolutions at a global scale.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of employing the TTOP-based scheme on the accuracy of permafrost monitoring across the Northern Hemisphere?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing the TTOP-based scheme, which utilizes input parameters such as temperature at the top of the permafrost, can improve the reliability of permafrost temperature and zonation maps. This method can offer a high-resolution overview, accounting for snow and land cover heterogeneity, and potentially lead to more precise models of permafrost area and temperature, thus supporting better understanding and management of these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the main objective of using remote sensing data to quantify the ecological regulation value of permafrost changes in the Arctic tundra?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to quantify the Arctic permafrost's ecological regulation service value by integrating multi-source remote sensing, simulation, statistical, and measured data using GIS and ecological methods. This involves assessing the correlation between active layer thickness, NDVI changes, and their relation to the ecosystem service value of tundra.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a focus on creating a high-resolution permafrost map for the Northern Hemisphere using the TTOP-based scheme?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The focus is on extending and improving remote sensing approaches to compile a Northern Hemisphere permafrost temperature and zonation map at a circum-Arctic scale with high resolution. This addresses the challenge of reliably detecting permafrost extent and occurrence at medium to high spatial resolutions globally, considering the spatial variability and distribution challenges.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data collection methods are employed to quantify the ecological regulation value of Arctic permafrost changes over the given time period?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methods used to quantify the ecological regulation value of Arctic permafrost changes include the integration of multi-source remote sensing data, simulation, statistical, and empirical data. Geographical Information System (GIS) techniques and ecological methods are combined to assess the changes, taking into account the correlation between active layer thickness, NDVI changes, and grassland ecosystem service values.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the TTOP-based scheme facilitate the development of permafrost temperature and zonation maps at a circum-Arctic scale?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TTOP-based scheme extends the remote sensing approach by compiling spatially distributed datasets of Thawing Degree Days (TDD) and Freezing Degree Days (FDD) using MODIS land surface temperature products. The scheme calculates mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost by integrating atmospheric lapse rates and elevation differences. This process allows the creation of permafrost temperature and zonation maps at a resolution of 1km2.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural challenges are associated with extrapolating permafrost extent to larger areas, and how are these addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Extrapolating permafrost extent to larger areas is challenged by considerable spatial variability in the ground thermal regime and uneven distribution of observation sites. These challenges are addressed by employing statistical representations of subpixel variability based on snow and landcover heterogeneity, and using the CryoGrid 1 model to adjust for snow cover and thermal offset effects in calculating MAGT.

Enablement.Question: What remote sensing technologies enable the high-resolution mapping of permafrost extent and temperature variability in the Arctic region?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometers (MODIS) on board the Terra and Aqua satellites provides land surface temperature (LST) measurements at a spatial resolution of 1km2, enabling the high-resolution mapping of permafrost extent and temperature variability in the Arctic region. Additionally, the TTOP equilibrium approach and CryoGrid 1 model are employed to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT).

Enablement.Question: How do statistical methods and spatial downscaling contribute to the accuracy of permafrost temperature datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Statistical methods contribute by providing a representation of subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures based on snow and landcover heterogeneity. Spatial downscaling of ERA-interim reanalysis data to a 1km2 resolution involves calculating atmospheric lapse rates and the elevation differences between ERA orography fields and MODIS pixels, which enhances the accuracy of permafrost temperature datasets.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be overcome to expand the spatial coverage of permafrost data collection in the Northern Hemisphere?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of observational sites, which result in extensive unsampled areas. Additionally, extended data gaps in the MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can introduce systematic biases, making it difficult to expand the spatial coverage of permafrost data collection.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset of permafrost extent and temperature fail to capture the full spatial variability of permafrost conditions?
Expectation.Answer: Extrapolating observations to larger regions is hampered by the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of sites, resulting in extensive unsampled areas.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise when using remote sensing data to estimate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) in permafrost regions?
Expectation.Answer: Extended data gaps in the remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages.

Expectation.Question: Why might a research approach based on mean annual air temperature (MAAT) and snow cover adjustments be inadequate for modeling permafrost temperature accurately?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy of the modelled mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) is ±2°C when compared to permafrost borehole data, indicating potential limitations in capturing the full complexity of the thermal effects of snow cover and other factors.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using remote sensing techniques for the spatial distribution of permafrost temperatures in the Northern Hemisphere?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of remote sensing techniques, specifically the TTOP-based scheme, has been effective in compiling the first permafrost temperature and zonation map at a circum-Arctic scale with a resolution of 1km2. The approach allows for a statistical representation of subpixel variability of permafrost temperatures based on snow and landcover heterogeneity, which is a significant advancement in addressing the spatial variability of the ground thermal regime.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in compiling datasets of permafrost extent and temperature at medium to high spatial resolutions?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and an uneven distribution of observation sites, leading to extensive unsampled areas. Furthermore, extended data gaps in MODIS LST time series due to cloud cover can result in a systematic cold bias in seasonal averages, complicating the extrapolation of observations to larger regions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits of integrating multiple data sources, such as remotely sensed and in-situ measurements, for studying permafrost changes?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources, such as remotely sensed land surface temperature products and in-situ borehole measurements, provides a more comprehensive understanding of permafrost changes. This approach enhances the accuracy of modeled mean annual ground temperature (MAGT) at the top of the permafrost, which has shown an accuracy of ±2°C. It also allows for a more reliable estimation of the permafrost area and its probability, which is crucial for understanding its ecological regulation value.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges faced in detecting permafrost extent with high spatial resolution across the Northern Hemisphere.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the considerable spatial variability in ground thermal regimes and the uneven distribution of measurement sites, which lead to unsampled areas. The lack of a reliable method at global scale and medium to high spatial resolutions adds to the difficulty.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe how remote sensing techniques can be integrated with ecological methods to quantify the ecological regulation value of permafrost changes in the Arctic region.
Request/Directive.Answer: The integration of remote sensing techniques with ecological methods involves using multi-source remote sensing data, simulations, statistical data, and field measurements to analyze changes in permafrost and their impact on ecological regulation. GIS and ecological methods are combined to quantify the ecological regulation value, with reference to the correlation between changes in active layer thickness and NDVI, which influences the valuation of tundra ecosystem services.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges encountered in detecting permafrost occurrence and extent at medium to high spatial resolutions on a global scale.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the considerable spatial variability of the ground thermal regime and the uneven distribution of sampling sites, leading to vast unsampled areas. Reliable detection is hampered by the lack of a consistent method to capture permafrost occurrences at these spatial resolutions globally. Additionally, extrapolating observations is difficult due to these variabilities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the process of compiling spatially distributed datasets from remotely sensed land surface temperature products for permafrost temperature modeling.
Request/Directive.Answer: The process involves using the CryoGrid 1 model based on the TTOP equilibrium approach to calculate mean annual ground temperature (MAGT). Remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) data from MODIS products are used to compile datasets of thawing degree days (TDD) and freezing degree days (FDD). Downscaling ERA-interim reanalysis data to 1km2 resolution is achieved by computing atmospheric lapse rates and adjusting for elevation differences between ERA orography and MODIS pixels.
